title: Can free will exist if we do not have the choice to accept or decline free will itself? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no. Yes, if you interpret free will to mean, the ability to do what we want. For example, you can choose between pizza or salad. If you want pizza, you can choose pizza, but, if you want salad, you can choose salad. Well people, that's obvious. In all of the time philosophers have been debating this matter, not one person has claimed that we do not have this ability. This is not the free will we're talking about. It's freedom of will. We have freedom of will, whether we believe we have free will or not. Personally I don't believe that we have free will, but I do believe that we have freedom of will. The ability to do what we want. So, what am I talking about? What is free will? Well, free will comes into play when I want pizza and I also want to eat healthy/lose weight. Free will is the ability to choose between two things I want. So, not choosing salad, when I want salad, but rather, choosing salad, when I want pizza. Do we possess such an ability? First, ask yourself, how can you want two opposite things? Are there 2 people inside you? In a manner of speaking, yes there are. We have 2 brains. One is logical and one is impulsive. One sees the big picture and seeks long term benifits, while the other seeks instant gratification. That first impulse to punch someone in the face if they irritate you, that's your impulsive brain. There's a reason your first impulse is to punch the person. Your impulsive brain reacts faster than your logical brain, which has to analyze the situation. You see, the purpose of the impulsive brain, is to take control in life or death situations, when speed is crucial. Your life may depend on it. When you feel threatened, your logical brain is put on the back burner. It has no say. Your impulsive brain takes control. Unfortunately, this leads to road rage. So, you now understand how we can have 2 opposing desires. Do we have the ability to choose? I'm going to let you absorb this a bit before I continue with my argument. Feel free to ask questions in comments if I'm not clear on anything.

Can free will exist if we do not have the choice to accept or decline free will itself? That would depend on what you imagine free free will to be. If you imagine it to be ‘doing what you want to do’ that’s a pretty meaningless definition isn’t it because everything you want to do you want to do & it’s actually impossible to willingly do something that you don’t ultimately want to do (i.e. more than not want to do) regardless of what it is - even crazy actions like self harming etc. But if free will is the ability to be free of error i.e. wisdom then it can only be wise to be able to act wisely & why would we want it any other way. Would you want to be unwise? U can’t believe anyone would if wisdom is something that’s supposed to be worth wanting & it is isn’t it?

There is nothing to suggest that we have free will, other than the feeling that we have it, that we are ‘free to choose.’ Saying that we have free will in some things and not others, is an indefensible argument, which requires so many qualifications that it collapses under the weight of its inconsistencies. Your question comically elucidates one of the inherent inconsistencies. “Can we use our free will to decline to use free will?” Also, I don’t think that anyone (except maybe a mystic) would want to argue that a newborn baby has freely chosen to be born at that particular place and time, to those particular parents, etc. So then, when, where and how does this mysterious power of free will come upon us? I would argue that if the existence of something cannot be confirmed by evidence, nor logically deduced, then we default to the conclusion that the thing does not exist.

Can free will exist if we do not have the choice to accept or decline free will itself? This is not a serious answer, however legit it might actually be. I just wanted to point out that this question sums up the basic understanding/philosophy of most BDSM fetishists on the planet. Thank you for attending my TED talk.

You can decline free will if you want to. You could drug yourself into a coma for example, removing your free will. If you want to be considered “living” and “conscious” and “human”, then free will is just part of the deal. No-one says you can have everything you want, even when what you want is contradictory.

Free action is constrained by basic biology and physics. Our constraints are defined by our humanity and our universe. Free will means we can make decisions that affect our human and universal experience, not that we have ultimate control. There are many things we can’t do by virtue of being trapped inside that biology and physics. You do not get the choice whether or not to be born, for example.

Yes, free will exists. Free will is not, however, omnipotence, nor does free will allow you to violate the principle of non-contradiction. Kudos, though: you made a masterful attempt at constructing an inherently illogical question. Have you got a bet going on how many people fall for it?

More basic than that. What is thought but electrical impulses generated in our brain? What we think is surely constrained by physical properties of what is in our brain, so we are not capable of thinking other than we do…free will simply means nobody else or nothing else is constraining us; not that we are “free” to choose in some absolute sense. As Nicholas Humphrey wrote: There was a young man who said "Damn!I perceive with regret that I amBut a creature that movesIn predestinate groovesNot even a bus, I'm a tram."
Free will, whether it exists or not, does not necessarily mean that all decisions are voluntarily chosen. It only suggests that some are.

Nobody has ever suggested that free will is not constrained by the necessities of the laws of physics or logic, or even of social pressure. Rather, free will operates within the sphere of what is possible. This is an accepted limitation.
